material.mattext: Which of the following is NOT a type of long-term memory?
The ability of a person to perceive fine details is known as:
The process by which we use the knowledge we have to draw conclusions or infer something new about the domain of interest is known as:
The three components of colour are:
Which of the following is a pointing device that does not require any additional space to operate and is often used in laptops?
Which of the following is NOT a factor that can limit the speed of an interactive system?
The "gulf of execution" refers to the difference between:
The user's understanding of the system and the system's actual behavior
The user's intended actions and the actions allowed by the system
The user's goals and the system's capabilities
The user's perception of the system state and the system's actual state
The cocktail party effect demonstrates that humans are able to:
Selectively attend to one stimulus over others
Remember information for a long period of time
Which of the following is NOT a type of reasoning discussed in the chapter?
Which of the following is NOT a common interface style?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a WIMP interface?
Which of the following is NOT a common WIMP element?
The initial stage of establishing what exactly is needed in the design process is referred to as:
The term used to describe rich stories of interaction, which can be used in conjunction with a method like task analysis or on their own to record and make vivid actual interaction is:
The term used to describe the main screens or modes within a system and how they interconnect is:
The four things to look for when looking at a single web page, screen, or state of a device in terms of navigation are:
Knowing where you are, knowing what you can do, knowing where you are going, and knowing where you've been.
Knowing where you are, knowing what you can do, knowing where you are going, and knowing who else is there.
Knowing where you are, knowing what you can do, knowing where you are going or what will happen, and knowing where you've been or what you've done.
Knowing where you are, knowing what you can do, knowing who else is there, and knowing where you've been or what you've done.
What is design in simple terms?
The process of creating something new.
Solving problems in a creative way.
Building a product that meets user needs.
What is the "golden rule of design"?
What is the core of interaction design?
Which of the following is NOT a benefit of using a hierarchy to organize a system?
It links screens or pages in logical groupings
It can reflect the menu structure of an application
It always matches the user's mental model
It can be used to structure a website
Why is iteration important in interaction design?
To ensure the design is aesthetically pleasing
To get the design right the first time
To improve the design based on evaluation and feedback
Evaluation performed at the end of the design process
The most abstract design rules are:
The ability of the user to evaluate the internal state of the system by means of its perceivable representation at the interface is known as:
The ability of the user to take corrective action once an error has been recognized is known as:
The extent to which a user's knowledge and experience in other domains can be applied when interacting with a new system is known as:
Which of the following is NOT one of Shneiderman's Eight Golden Rules of Interface Design?
Design rules that are high in authority and limited in application are known as:
Which of the following is NOT one of Norman's Seven Principles?
Use both knowledge in the world and knowledge in the head
Provide flexibility and efficiency of use
How the user perceives the rate of communication with the system is known as:
The ability of the user to extend knowledge of specific interaction within and across applications to other similar situations is known as:
The 'formality gap' in software design refers to the:
Difference between formal and informal specifications
Gap between the customer's needs and the designer's understanding
Disparity between the real world and the structured design process
Difference in the level of detail between architectural and detailed design
Which prototyping approach involves building the final product as separate components, one at a time?
Which of the following is NOT a benefit of using design rationale?
It provides a communication mechanism among the members of a design team
It allows for the reuse of design knowledge across different projects
It guarantees the usability of the final product
It encourages careful deliberation about design decisions
Which prototyping technique involves creating a graphical depiction of the system without any functionality?
Which of the following is a characteristic of the 'evolutionary prototyping' approach?
The prototype is built and tested, then discarded, and the final product is built from scratch
The final product is built as separate components, one at a time
The prototype is not discarded but serves as the basis for the next iteration of design
The prototype is built using a high-level programming language to simulate functionality
The primary goal of usability engineering is to:
Ensure that the system is aesthetically pleasing
Incorporate user feedback throughout the design process
Use explicit criteria to judge the success of a product in terms of its usability
Which of the following is an example of a 'usability metric'?
The number of errors made by users during a task
The time taken to complete a task
User satisfaction ratings on a Likert scale
